title: Battery Robinett

images.altText: Colonel Rogers grave at Battery Robinett
images.title: Battery Robinett
images.caption: Colonel Rogers Grave at Battery Robinett

bodyText: Battery Robinett was one of the earthen fortifications ordered constructed by Union General William Roscrans. The wedge shaped work was thirty-five yards wide by forty yards deep. The battery housed three 20-pounder Parrot rifles and the walls were reinforced with gabions and fascines. The approaches were obstructed by abatis. The strength of the fortification proved effective against the Confederate assualts during the October 1862 battle of Corinth.

title: Bloody Pond - Tour Stop #19
listingDescription: Bloody Pond. Reportedly, wounded men and animals found their way to this water source, and turned the water blood red while drinking and washing their wounds.

images.altText: A lone cannon stands sentinel over a pool of water
images.title: Artillery at Blooody Pond
images.caption: Bloody Pond

bodyText: This sector of the battlefield, which surrounds this vernal pool, witnessed heavy fighting. Confederate forces seized it on April 6; Buell's forces retook it the next day.

title: Confederate Monument - Tour Stop #2
listingDescription: Erected by the United Daughters of the Confederacy in 1917, this monument, designed and sculpted by Frederick C. Hibbard, honors all Southern troops who fought in the Battle of Shiloh.

images.altText: Photograph of the Confederate Monument at Shiloh
images.title: Photograph of the Confederate Monument at Shiloh
images.caption: Confederate Monument at Shiloh

bodyText:
This monument, designed and sculptured by Frederick C. Hibbard, was erected in 1917 by the United Daughters of the Confederacy in memory of all Southern troops who fought in the battle.

In the center of the massive pedestal is carved the bust of Gen. Albert Sidney Johnston, the Confederate commander who was killed during the afternoon of the first day.

At the extreme right, the figure in front represents the Confederate infantryman who has snatched up his flag in defiance of the Northern army. The figure to his rear is the artilleryman, who is calm as he appears to gaze through the smoke of battle.

To the left, the figure in front represents the cavalryman. His hand is spread, indicating frustration. He is eager to help, but cannot penetrate the heavy undergrowth. The figure back of the cavalryman represents the officers of the Confederate army. He has his head bowed in submission to the order to cease firing when, it seemed, had it not been given the first day, there might have been a Confederate victory.

The central group represents a "Defeated Victory." The front figure, representing the Confederacy, is surrendering the laurel wreath of victory to Death, on the left, and Night, on the right. Death came to their commander and Night brought reinforcements to the enemy, and the battle was lost.

The panel of heads on the right represents the spirit of the first day. How hopefully and fearlessly the 11 young Confederates rushed into battle! The panel of heads on the left represents the second day of the battle and the sorrow of the men, now reduced to 10, over the victory so nearly won and so unexpectedly lost.

quickFacts.value: Erected to honor all Confederate troops who fought in the Battle of Shiloh
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: National Park, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Confederates Gain Ground - Tour Stop #8
listingDescription: Confederates Gain Ground

images.altText: A historic picture of a Union general
images.title: Gen. Benjamin Prentiss
images.caption: Brigadier General Benjamin Prentiss

bodyText: Early in the morning on April 6, Prentiss' men deployed along the low ridge in front of you and tried to halt the Confederate onslaught surging north across this ground. Within an hour, the Federals were forced back to their camps, with Johnston and his men in close pursuit.

title: Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center
listingDescription: The Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center

images.altText: Image of a brick building with American flag flying out front
images.title: Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center
images.caption: Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center

bodyText:
Corinth, Mississippi, a town with an 1860 population of more than 1,500, was established at the crossover of the Memphis and Charleston and the Mobile and Ohio Railroads during the 1850s. It was initially known as Cross City. It is located in the northeast corner of Mississippi near the Tennessee border, 22 miles southwest of Pittsburg Landing, on the Tennessee River, where on April 6-7, 1862, the terrible battle of Shiloh was fought. In the years since the Civil War, Corinth has grown into a small city, but the general landscape has changed little. Several small streams (Cane, Bridge, Phillips, Elam, and Turner creeks) meander through the area. The soft rolling hills, mixed pine and hardwood forests, and open farmland resemble the terrain of southern Tennessee.

Located near the site of Battery Robinett, the Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center, is open from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm every day except Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day. Center exhibits include interactive displays and multimedia presentations on the Battle of Shiloh and the Siege and Battle of Corinth. The culminating interpretive feature is a commemorative courtyard where stone and flowing water chronicle the birth and growth of the United States, the accompanying rise of sectionalism, key events leading to the Civil War, and a symbolic representation of four years of war.

title: Daniel Davis Wheatfield - Tour Stop #15
listingDescription: Some of the heaviest fighting of the second day of Shiloh took place in the Daniel Davis Wheatfield.

images.credit: PHOTOGRAPHIC HISTORY OF THE CIVIL WAR, VOL. 2
images.altText: Historic image of Civil War soldiers in front of a tent
images.title: Washington Light Artillery
images.caption: Members of the Washington Light Artillery, 5th Company

bodyText:
Confedrates seized this area on April 6 during the assaults on the Hornets' Nest to the north. On the second day, Buell's forces proceded rather easily over the battlefield until running into the first major Confederate defensive line at this postion on the Hamburg-Purdy Road. Here on April 7, the famed Washington Light Artillery from New Orleans unlimbered and reportedly fired 60 rounds at the approaching enemy. 

The attacking Federals of Hazen's Brigade neared the muzzles of the Washington Artillery taking heavy casaulties, including four color bearers of the 41st Ohio shot down. In fact, Hazen's three regiments suffered more casualties than any of Buell's or Lew Wallace's other reinforcing brigades on this day. 

Hazen's men captured the guns of the Washington Artillery shooting down many cannoneers and horses, but the victory was short lived. A counterattack by the Crescent Regiment and 19th Louisiana Infantry retook the guns from the 41st Ohio pushing them back through the field. 

However, even with the determined Confederate defense in this area, the southerners lacked the power or numbers to push the fresh Federals off the field. Even so, Union general Thomas Crittenden would say that the fighting he witnessed in the Daniel Davis Wheatfield was the fiercest he saw during the entire war. 

The death of one Confederate private here, Samuel B. Todd, of the Crescent Regiment, would personally touch the White House, for Samuel's half-sister was First Lady Mary Todd Lincoln.

title: Davis Bridge Battlefield

images.altText: Image of a body of water, flanked by trees
images.title: Hatchie River
images.caption: Wide Bend in the Hatchie River

bodyText: The heavy fighting at the Battle of Corinth, October 3 & 4, 1862, had crippled the Confederate Army, forcing them to retreat toward Mississippi to rest and refit. The path to safety ran across Davis Bridge on the Hatchie River in Tennessee. Union forces under General Edward O.C. Ord were rushed from Boliver, Tennessee, to block the Confederate escape. The Battle of Davis Bridge would take place on October 5, 1862. The Confederates were able to escape, but only at a high cost in casualties.

title: Death of Albert Sidney Johnston - Tour Stop #17
listingDescription: Albert Sidney Johnston was the second highest ranking general in the Confederate army and commander of all Confederate forces in the Western Theater. A stray bullet at the Battle of Shiloh would cost the Confederacy the general that Jefferson Davis considered to be America's greatest soldier.

images.altText: A monument featuring cannon balls and a cannon.
images.title: Johnston Mortuary Monument
images.caption: Johnston Mortuary Monument

bodyText:
The monument here marks the site where the Confederate commander, Gen. Albert Sidney Johnston, was taken after being found wounded on April 6. That afternoon, Johnston ordered his reserves to go into action and advance on the right flank in an attempt to drive a wedge between the Federal troops and their base of supplies at Pittsburg Landing. He also hoped to make it impossible for reinforcements to come to Grant's assistance from across the river. While personally directing his reserves, he was struck behind the right knee by a Minie ball, which cut the large artery.

At the time General Johnston was struck, he was sitting on his horse "Fireeater." He was taken to the ravine about 100 yards south of this monument by his staff members. There he died from loss of blood a few minutes later, ironically with an unused tourniquet in his pocket. Johnston was the highest ranking officer killed in combat during the Civil War and remains the highest ranking American military officer ever to be killed in action. After his death, command of the Confederate army passed to General P.G.T. Beauregard.

This monument is one of five on the Shiloh battlefield that were erected in 1902 by the United States government to pay tribute to and mark the spot where high ranking officers were killed in the Battle of Shiloh. At each corner of the concrete base is a pyramid of 8" shells and in the center is a 30 pdr. Parrott tube mounted vertically bearing a bronze plaque with the inscription and capped by a 12 pdr. shell.

quickFacts.value: Marks the site of the death of Albert Sidney Johnston, Confederate commander at the Battle of Shiloh
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: National Park, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Dill Branch Ravine - Tour Stop #20
listingDescription: Where two Union gunboats fired upon attacking Confederate infantry in the late afternoon of April 6. They would continue to lob shells into the Confederate lines that evening.

images.altText: Two 32-pounder cannon overlook Dill Branch
images.title: Dill Branch Ravine
images.caption: Naval Guns at Dill Branch

bodyText: Near sundown on April 6, two wooden gunboats (timberclads), the Lexington and Tyler, anchored opposite the mouth of Dill Branch to add naval support to Grant's defense of Pittsburg Landing. Cannon fire from these vessels helped repulse the final Confederate assault of the day across this rugged ravine.

title: Duncan Field - Tour Stop #3

images.altText: A monument and fence mark the location of the Sunken Road
images.title: Sunken Road
images.caption: Union Position along the Sunken Road

bodyText: Union troops stubbornly held this position throughout the day of April 6, giving Grant time to prepare a strong defensive line closer to Pittsburg Landing. On April 7, soldiers from Buell's army steadily pressed John C. Breckinridge's Confederate corps southward to recover this sector of the battlefield.

title: Field Hospital - Tour Stop #16

images.altText: Image of a fence surrounding a Union monument.
images.title: Tent Hospital Site
images.caption: Tent Hospital Site at Shiloh

bodyText:
Here a surgeon from Buell's army established one of the first tent hospitals of the Civil War. On the afternoon of April 7, Captain Bernard J. D. Irwin opened up a surgical station in a farmhouse on this site. By April 8, he had created a 300 bed surigical hospital complete with an operating room, dispensary, office, kitchen, and medical officers' dining room. 

By concentrating medical services on the actual field of battle, rather than transport the wounded considerable distances offsite to general hospitals well beyond the contesting armies, patient care was greatly improved and the death rate was lowered.

quickFacts.value: First field hospital on the front lines
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fraley Field - Tour Stop #7

images.altText: A picture of an open field with a cast iron sign post.
images.title: Fraley Field
images.caption: Fraley Field

bodyText:
The short trail to the west leads to Fraley Field where fighting commenced at 4:55 am on April 6, when Confederate pickets engaged a patrol from Colonel Everett Peabody's brigade. 

Leading "Peabody's Patrol" was an experienced regular US Army officer named Major James Powell. As he and his small force of 250 men stepped out of the woods and into Fraley Field, skirmishers of Aaron B. Hardcastle's 3rd Mississippi Battalion opened fire. The battle of Shiloh had begun. 

The skirmish between these two small forces lasted about an hour. This alerted the Union camps and the complete surprise Johnston and Beauregard had hoped for disappeared.

title: Grant's Last Line - Tour Stop #1
listingDescription: With his army surprised by the Confederate attack and on the verge of being driven from the field, General Ulysses S. Grant massed 51 pieces of artillery (including heavy siege guns) and dug fortifications in a last-ditch effort to save his army.

images.altText: Civil War cannon in the fog
images.title: Siege Guns in Fog
images.caption: Siege Guns on Grant's Last Line

bodyText:
The siege guns in front of you mark the position of Captain Relly Madison's Battery B, 2nd Illinois Light Artillery. They served as the anchor point for Grant's Last Line of defense. Grant's Chief of Staff, Col. Joseph Dana Webster, was tasked to form this successful last defensive postion near the end of fighting on April 6. From here, the Federals launched a counterattack on April 7.   

Madison's Battery consisted of five M1819 24-pounder Iron Siege Guns, and one 8-inch Siege Howitzer (64-pounder) used on the second day of fighting. In all, Grant and Webster assembled 50 cannon and nearly 20,000 infantry on this Last Line of defense before General Buell started offloading his army from transports on the evening of April 6.

quickFacts.value: Final defensive postion establish by Federals before launching counterattack against Confederates
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: National Park, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Grant's Left Flank - Tour Stop #21
listingDescription: The left flank of Grant's army on the evening of April 6.

images.altText: Cannon on the bluff overlooking Dill Branch ravine.
images.title: Grant's Left Flank
images.caption: Artillery Supporting Grant's Left Flank.

bodyText: Here, Union artillery hammered the Confederate infantry's right flank as it charged across the rugged Dill Branch ravine on April 6th. This is the far left flank of "Grant's Last Line" of defense in the late afternoon of the first day of fighting.

title: Hornets' Nest - Tour Stop #10
listingDescription: There is perhaps no more famous Civil War icon than the Hornets' Nest at Shiloh. Ranking with Pickett's Charge at Gettysburg, Bloody Lane at Antietam, and the Stone Wall at Fredericksburg, Shiloh's Hornet's Nest is well known to even the most novice Civil War student.

images.altText: Modern photo of Shiloh's Hornet's Nest
images.title: Modern photo of Shiloh's Hornet's Nest
images.description: The Hornet's Nest at Shiloh battlefield
images.caption: The Hornet's Nest at Shiloh battlefield

bodyText:
Shiloh's Hornets' Nest refers to a nearly six-hundred-yard stretch of what came to be known as the Sunken Road in the center of the battlefield and was the scene of heavy combat on both days of the battle. On the first day, elements of three Union divisions manned the line along a little-used farm road that ran through the Joseph Duncan property. Duncan and his family worked a small cotton field that bordered the road to the south. With its open fields of fire and road cover, there is little wonder that the Duncan plot became one of the most important localities on the battlefield.

This position, atop a small rise and fronting an almost impenetrable undergrowth, became the target of the numerous Confederate attacks on April 6. Heavy fighting raged in the area of the Hornets' Nest on the first day, with no less than eight distinct Confederate attacks turned back by the determined defenders of the Sunken Road. Attesting to the fury in the area, Confederates so named the location because, they said, the enemy's bullets sounded like swarms of angry hornets.

Confederate General Daniel Ruggles, after having witnessed the unsuccessful attacks against the position, formed a line of artillery consisting of as many as 53 big guns and concentrated its fire upon the Federal line. With the aid of these cannon, the Confederates were able to form a circle around the Hornets' Nest, surrounding and capturing General Prentiss, with nearly 2,200 troops, late in the day on April 6.

quickFacts.value: Scene of some of some of the heaviest fighting during the Battle of Shiloh
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: National Park, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Invasion of the Union Camps - Tour Stop #9

images.altText: An image of Colonel Peabody's mortuary monument
images.title: Peabody Mortuary Monument
images.caption: Col. Everett Peabody's Mortuary Monument

bodyText: Soldiers from Prentiss' division made a brief defense of their camps along their camp color line before being forced to retire north at 9:00 am. The victorius Confederate soldiers stopped to plunder the captured camps, briefly stalling the offensive.

title: Jones Field - Tour Stop #12
listingDescription: Jones Field

images.altText: Picture of Union position markers in Jones Field
images.title: Jones Field
images.caption: Union Position Tablets in Jones Field

bodyText: Union forces rallied here late in the morning of April 6, mounting a counterattack that briefly checked the Confederate offensive before being forced to withdraw across Tilghman Branch. Grant's troops, reinforced by Lew Wallace's division on the right, recovered this field the next day, driving the Confederate line back to Shiloh Church.

title: Orientation Shelter - Tour Stop #1
listingDescription: Shiloh Indian Mounds Shelter and trailhead.

images.altText: A stone building
images.title: Shiloh Indian Mounds Orientation Shelter
images.caption: Shiloh Indian Mounds Orientation Shelter

bodyText: Begin your tour at the Orientation Shelter and learn about this prehistoric village and its people.

title: Peach Orchard - Tour Stop #18

images.altText: Luminaries light the Peach Orchard
images.title: Peach Orchard
images.caption: Luminaries Light the Peach Orchard

bodyText: Sarah Bell's orchard was in full bloom when Confederates attacked Union forces here on April 6. The Federal army eventually retreated to Pittsburg Landing, but retook the field the next day.

title: Pittsburg Landing - Tour Stop #22
listingDescription: Pittsburg Landing on the Tennessee River

images.altText: A park wayside exhibit overlooks the Tennessee River
images.title: Pittsburg Landing
images.caption: Pittsburg Landing

bodyText: The roads linking this landing southward to Corinth, Mississippi, was one of the reasons William T. Sherman selected this site to stage the Federal army in mid-March. Key to the battlefield, the failure of the Confederate army to seize or deny use of the landing permitted Buell's Army of the Ohio to reinforce Grant's bloodied army during the night of April 6-7.

title: Rhea Field - Tour Stop #6

images.credit: Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division Washington
images.altText: Men in a black and white photograph pose in camp
images.title: Members of the 6th Mississippi in Camp
images.caption: Members of the 6th Mississippi in Camp

bodyText: Exposed to converging musket and artillery fire from the Federals defending Shiloh Church early on April 6, Confederate units suffered devastating losses as they struggled across Shiloh Branch. The 6th Mississippi Infantry Regiment alone suffered 70% casualties in less than an hour.

title: Ruggles' Battery - Tour Stop #4
listingDescription: Tour Stop #4, Ruggels' Battery

images.altText: Dozens of cannon lined up on Duncan Field
images.title: Ruggles' Battery
images.caption: Ruggles' Battery

bodyText: When infantry attacks against the Hornets' Nest failed, the Confederates bombarded it with 11 batteries of artillery, a total of 53 big guns. This concentrated artillery bombardment on the Union position, in addition to the infantry converging on the Federal flanks, led to the capture of General Benjamin Prentiss and nearly 2,200 Union soldiers.

title: Shiloh Auto Tour Conclusion
listingDescription: The end of the Shiloh battlefield auto tour.

images.altText: An historic image of older veterans of Shiloh gathered together
images.title: Shiloh Veterans' Reunion ca. 1895
images.caption: Shiloh Veterans' Reunion ca. 1895

bodyText: This is the end of the auto driving tour of Shiloh National Military Park. Please make sure to visit the Corinth Civil War Interpretive Center and learn more about the Civil War in the western theater.

title: Shiloh Battlefield Book Store
listingDescription: Shiloh's bookstore, operated by America's National Parks. Offers educational items and souvenirs related to the Battle of Shiloh, Siege and Battle of Corinth, and the Civil War in the western theater.

images.altText: A brick building with yellow trim.
images.title: Shiloh Battlefield Bookstore
images.caption: The Bookstore at Shiloh

bodyText: The Shiloh bookstore is operated by the America's National Parks a non-profit education partner of the National Park Service.
passportStampLocationDescription: The Shiloh bookstore has five different passport stamps available for visitors.

passportStampImages.altText: Passport stamp for the Shiloh National Cemetery
passportStampImages.title: Shiloh National Cemetery Stamp

title: Shiloh Battlefield Self-Guided Tour Introduction
listingDescription: Shiloh Visitor Center

images.altText: Painting of the fighting in the Hornets Nest
images.title: Hornet's Nest
images.caption: Lindsay's Hornet's Nest

bodyText:
On April 6 and 7, 1862, the woods and open fields surrounding the Shiloh Meeting House became the largest battleground in the history of the Western Hemisphere up to that time. Almost 110,000 in blue and gray fought one another in the fiercest fighting ever seen by this nation. By the end of the battle 23,476 soldiers were either dead, wounded, or missing. The butcher's bill at Shiloh exceeded the United States' casualty numbers from all previous wars combined. It was a shock to the nation, and a portent of battles to come. 

In 1894, Congress established Shiloh National Military Park to commemorate and honor those who fought and sacrificed at Shiloh. American's set aside and continue to preserve this land so future generations will not forget the terrible carnage that occured in April of 1862. Monumentation, position tablets, and cannon now mark the spots where men battled to the death 160 years ago. 

The 22-stop audio tour will examine some of the more important sites in the Battle of Shiloh.

multimedia.title: Introduction to the Shiloh Auto Driving Tour

title: Shiloh Church - Tour Stop #5

images.altText: Painting of the Shiloh Church
images.title: Shiloh Church
images.caption: A.M. Connett's Painting of Shiloh Church (ca. 1901)

bodyText: Here stood the Shiloh Meeting House, the log Methodist church that gave the battle its name. After three hours of brutal fighting on the morning of April 6, the Confederates seized this position from William T. Sherman's division, which had been camped along this ridge for three weeks.

title: Shiloh Indian Mounds Orientation Shelter
listingDescription: The Shiloh Indian Mounds Shelter is where you begin your exploration of this ancient village. Interpretive exhibits introduce the story of this culture and a tactile map is on display showcasing the entire village. The trailhead for the Indian Mounds Trail is located here.

images.altText: A small structure made of white stone.
images.title: Indian Mounds Shelter
images.caption: Shiloh Indian Mounds Orientation Shelter

bodyText: The Shiloh Indian Mounds Shelter is where you begin your exploration of this ancient village. Interpretive exhibits introduce the story of this culture and a tactile map is on display showcasing the entire village. A site bulletin with an Indian Mounds trail map is also available here. The 1.1-mile walking trail takes visitors through the heart of the village and over the largest mound.

quickFacts.value: Shiloh Indian Mounds National Historical  Landmark
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Shiloh National Cemetery
listingDescription: Shiloh National Cemetery is open from dawn until dusk everyday.

images.altText: A monument of three cannon marking Grants HQ on April 6, 1862
images.title: Grant's Headquarters Marker in Cemetery
images.caption: Grant's Headquarters Monument in National Cemetery

bodyText:
In 1866, the War Department established a cemetery on the battlefield of Shiloh, in southwestern Tennessee. In order to bury the dead not only from the April 6-7, 1862, battle of Shiloh but also from all the operations along the Tennessee River, workers began building the "Pittsburg Landing National Cemetery." Changed to "Shiloh National Cemetery" in 1889, the cemetery holds 3,584 Civil War dead, 2,359 of them unknown. In the fall of 1866, workers disinterred the dead from 156 locations on the battlefield, and 565 different locations along the Tennessee River. Headboards of wood first marked each grave, but were replaced in 1876 and 1877 by granite stones. Tall stones marked the known dead and square, short stones denoted unknown soldiers.

Workers built a stone wall around the cemetery in 1867, and fashioned ornamental iron gates at the entrance in 1911. A superintendent cared for the cemetery until it was officially consolidated with Shiloh National Military Park in 1943. The results of so much labor produced what one observer called "the handsomest cemetery in the South."

Although established as a Civil War burial ground, the Shiloh National Cemetery now holds deceased soldiers from later American wars. Many World War I and II, Korea, and Vietnam burials are in the newest section of the cemetery. There is also one Persian Gulf War memorial. Total interred in the cemetery now stands as 3,892. Although the cemetery was officially closed in 1984, it still averages two or three burials a year, mostly widows of soldiers already interred.

quickFacts.value: Final resting place of 3,584 Union and 2 Confederate soldiers who fell near Shiloh, Tennessee
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: National Park, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Shiloh Picnic Pavilion
listingDescription: Shiloh's Picnic Area

images.altText: Brown sign with wooden pavilion in the background.
images.title: Shiloh Picnic Area
images.caption: Shiloh Picnic Area

bodyText:
The Shiloh picnic pavilion was built during the National Park Service's "Mission 66" project in preparation for the 50th anniversary in 1966. Today it houses dozens of picnic tables, some of which are accessible, for family gatherings, group events, or a quick bite. Fully accessible restrooms and a new water bottle filling station are also on site. 

There is no reservation system at Shiloh, so the pavilion is first-come, first served. Please be kind and pack out or throw away all trash and left-over food.

title: Shiloh's Casualties - Tour Stop #11
listingDescription: Confederate Burial Trench

images.altText: Picture of a monument marking one of the Confederate burial sites
images.title: Confederate Burial Trench
images.caption: Confederate Burial Trench

bodyText: After the battle, Union soldiers dug several trenches to bury the 1,728 Confederates killed in the fighting. This is one of five known to be on the battlefield. When the park was established, Shiloh veterans chose to honor and preserve the Confederate graves as important historical features of the battle and the Civil War.

title: Signs of Dwellings - Tour Stop #2

images.altText: A painting of prehistoric dwellings
images.title: Dwellings
images.caption: Prehistoric waddle and daub dwellings.

bodyText:
The house mounds scattered throughout the complex are the remnants of collapsed houses. There are more than 65 identified house mounds within the Shiloh Indian Mound village.  

The dwellings were built using wattle and daub. The wattle was river cane that was woven to create the walls and roof; the walls were then covered in daub, a plaster like material that coated the river cane. The houses were circular and in the center sat a hearth on the dirt floor.

title: The Center of Town - Tour Stop #3
listingDescription: Center of the thriving Indian village

images.altText: A painting of the Indian Mound village.
images.title: Shiloh Indian Mound Village
images.caption: Shiloh Indian Mound Village

bodyText: The heart of this thriving Mississippian era village.

title: Water Oaks Pond - Tour Stop #14

images.altText: Picture of a pond on Shiloh Battlefield
images.title: Water Oaks Pond
images.caption: Water Oaks Pond

bodyText: A sector of the battlefield that witnessed unparalleled slaughter during the first day of battle, troops were again heavily engaged here during the afternoon of April 7. The desperate assaults that General P.G.T. Beauregard hurled through this wet weather pond on April 7 failed to halt the stronger Union counteroffensive. With chances for victory gone, Beauregard withdrew his army to Corinth.

title: Woolf Field - Tour Stop #13
listingDescription: Woolf Field

images.altText: The Tennessee monument in Woolf Field
images.title: Tennessee State Monument
images.caption: Tennessee State Monument

bodyText: At noon, April 6, General Grant's struggling right wing, led by Gernerals William T. Sherman and John McClernand, counterattacked southward one-half mile from Jones Field to briefly recapture this sector. Severe fighting raged along this front until the depleted Federal ranks retired fighting at 2 pm.

quickFacts.value: Some of the most severe fighting at Shiloh occurred in Woolf Field
quickFacts.name: Significance
